text: Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.

text: Patient: Uh, is difficult because I wake up in the morning, and I can feel some pain, strain or whatever. Uh, it’s strange that when I go and I had the two blood transfusions, that I could be on that table for five hours, laying on my back, and I don’t have no problem. I don’t know what the correlation that is. I tried to lift the bed up, and, uh, the, uh, the foot part, and I guess I haven’t found the, uh, the right position yet for it, for me that, that works. Uh, the, uh, but for the most part, we’ve been, we’ve been working through it. Doctor: How many oxycodone are you taking now? Patient: Uh. Doctor: Looking at this list. Patient: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.

text: Patient: All of it. Doctor: And, so you didn’t get any kind of call from the company that did the test? Patient: No. Doctor: As far as you know? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But –

text: Family Member: The radium since it’s an injection is it IV injection or just a shot? Doctor: It is. No, they put a little IV in and then they kind of push it in over a minute and then you’re good for the month. Now, technically that’s liquid radiation so you’re kind of glowy. Patient: Ah. Okay. Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation. Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal?

Patient: Okay. So, if I stay on this for three months, it’s most likely that, uh, let’s say it’s group two (for sake of argument) Doctor: Correct. For the current cohort, uh, oh, one slot left. Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um.

text: Family Member: We’re done. Doctor: Oh yes, I’m just checking. And how is it? Do you love it? Family Member: Yeah, it’s uh; we have to make some changes but yeah, it feels like home. Doctor: That’s awesome, no ladders for you, right? Family Member: I had to argue with him about it. Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
